title: Data Definition Language (DDL)
description: Question-first, runnable DDL patterns for DuckDB: CREATE, CTAS, ALTER (basics), TRUNCATE equivalent, DROP, plus copy-structure and temporary-table techniques. All examples are idempotent and finish with a SELECT to show results. Each includes cross-engine compatibility notes.

sections.title: 0. Introduction: DDL Basics in DuckDB
sections.narrative: This lesson covers practical, runnable DDL patterns for DuckDB: creating tables (plain and CTAS), adding columns safely, IF NOT EXISTS guards, temporary tables, copying structure (WHERE 1=0), and safe drops. All examples are idempotent and deterministic to pass validation.
sections.nerd_notes: DuckDB is embedded and file-backed. Prefer patterns that are re-runnable: DROP IF EXISTS before CREATE, or OR REPLACE CTAS for snapshots. End examples with a SELECT for stable output.

sections.title: 1. Create tables safely

examples.name: create_tables
examples.description: Question: How do I create a table idempotently and seed a few rows?
examples.nerd_notes: Use DROP TABLE IF EXISTS before CREATE to make examples re-runnable. Keep small seed data deterministic and include an ORDER BY for stable outputs.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE authors (author_id INT PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT); INSERT INTO authors VALUES (1,'Ana'),(2,'Ben');
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TABLE authors (author_id INT PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR(255)); INSERT INTO authors VALUES (1,'Ana'),(2,'Ben');
compat_examples.sqlite: CREATE TABLE authors (author_id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT); INSERT INTO authors VALUES (1,'Ana'),(2,'Ben');
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE authors (author_id NUMBER PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR2(255)); INSERT INTO authors VALUES (1,'Ana'); INSERT INTO authors VALUES (2,'Ben');

sections.narrative: Create objects and small sample data used by subsequent examples. Keep these steps idempotent.
sections.nerd_notes: Practical note: this example is simplified for teaching. See the nerd notes in each example for tips and production caveats.

sections.title: 1.5 Cheat Sheet: Quick DDL Patterns
sections.narrative: Fast, copy‑pasteable DDL snippets. All examples are self-contained and idempotent.

examples.name: cs_or_replace_ctas_quick
examples.description: Create-or-replace a small snapshot table via CTAS (idempotent).
examples.nerd_notes: OR REPLACE makes CTAS re-runnable without a prior DROP in engines that support it. We still drop first for portability when copying the pattern elsewhere.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW cs_snapshot_v AS SELECT 1 AS id, 'ok' AS status; -- or use CREATE TABLE with DROP IF EXISTS for strict table semantics
compat_examples.mysql: -- No CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE; use: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cs_snapshot; CREATE TABLE cs_snapshot AS SELECT 1 id, 'ok' status;
compat_examples.sqlite: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cs_snapshot; CREATE TABLE cs_snapshot AS SELECT 1 AS id, 'ok' AS status;

examples.name: cs_add_column_with_default_quick
examples.description: Add a column with DEFAULT safely, then verify it exists.
examples.nerd_notes: Defaults keep legacy rows consistent. Use PRAGMA table_info or information_schema.columns to verify structure.

compat_examples.postgres: ALTER TABLE cs_books ADD COLUMN in_stock BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE;
compat_examples.mysql: ALTER TABLE cs_books ADD COLUMN in_stock BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE;
compat_examples.oracle: ALTER TABLE cs_books ADD (in_stock NUMBER(1) DEFAULT 1);

examples.name: cs_like_copy_shape_quick
examples.description: Copy only the structure of a table (no rows).
examples.nerd_notes: DuckDB lacks CREATE TABLE LIKE; use CTAS with a false predicate to copy schema.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE cs_like (LIKE cs_src INCLUDING ALL);
compat_examples.sqlite: CREATE TABLE cs_like AS SELECT * FROM cs_src WHERE 0;
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE cs_like AS SELECT * FROM cs_src WHERE 1=0;

examples.name: cs_temp_table_count_quick
examples.description: Create a TEMP table and count rows.
examples.sql:
CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE cs_temp AS SELECT * FROM range(3) AS t(i);
SELECT COUNT(*) AS n FROM cs_temp;
examples.nerd_notes: Temporary tables are session-scoped; no explicit DROP needed.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TEMP TABLE cs_temp AS SELECT generate_series(0,2) AS i;
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE cs_temp (i INT); INSERT INTO cs_temp VALUES (0),(1),(2);
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE cs_temp (i NUMBER) ON COMMIT PRESERVE ROWS; INSERT INTO cs_temp SELECT LEVEL-1 FROM dual CONNECT BY LEVEL <= 3;

sections.title: 1.6 Pitfalls, Tips, and Q&A
sections.narrative: Common DDL gotchas and best practices when working with DuckDB and portable SQL.

examples.name: pitfall_if_not_exists_can_hide_typos
examples.description: Using IF NOT EXISTS everywhere can hide mistakes; prefer DROP+CREATE in migrations and tests for determinism.

examples.name: tip_or_replace_ctas_for_snapshots
examples.description: Use CREATE OR REPLACE TABLE ... AS SELECT for idempotent snapshot tables during demos.

examples.name: question_pk_enforcement_in_duckdb
examples.description: DuckDB stores PRIMARY KEY/UNIQUE metadata but doesn't enforce all constraints like full FK; validate with separate checks.

examples.name: tricky_drop_schema_dependencies
examples.description: Dropping a schema with CASCADE removes contained objects; preview with information_schema before destructive operations.

examples.name: fundamental_copy_swap_for_type_changes
examples.description: For type changes and renames, use copy-swap staging tables (see altertable.json) for safer, reversible migrations.

sections.title: 2. Create with constraints

examples.name: create_with_constraints
examples.description: Question: How do I add NOT NULL, CHECK, and PRIMARY KEY constraints when creating a table?
examples.nerd_notes: DuckDB records PRIMARY KEY metadata but doesn't enforce all FK semantics. Use CHECK for invariants like non-negative prices.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE books (book_id INT PRIMARY KEY, title TEXT NOT NULL, author_id INT REFERENCES authors(author_id), price NUMERIC CHECK (price >= 0));
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TABLE books (book_id INT PRIMARY KEY, title VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, author_id INT, price DECIMAL(10,2) CHECK (price >= 0), FOREIGN KEY (author_id) REFERENCES authors(author_id));
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE books (book_id NUMBER PRIMARY KEY, title VARCHAR2(255) NOT NULL, author_id NUMBER, price NUMBER CHECK (price >= 0))

sections.narrative: Define key integrity rules at creation time for clarity and better data quality.
sections.nerd_notes: DuckDB supports CHECK/NOT NULL and stores PK/UNIQUE metadata. For full FK enforcement, see notes in the constraints lessons.

sections.title: 3. ALTER best practices

examples.name: alter_best_practices
examples.sql:
ALTER TABLE books ADD COLUMN in_stock BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE;
SELECT * FROM books ORDER BY book_id;
examples.description: Question: How can I add a column safely without breaking existing queries?
examples.nerd_notes: Adding columns with DEFAULT keeps old rows consistent. For type changes or renames, prefer the copy pattern (see altertable.json).

compat_examples.postgres: ALTER TABLE books ADD COLUMN in_stock BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE;
compat_examples.mysql: ALTER TABLE books ADD COLUMN in_stock BOOLEAN DEFAULT TRUE;
compat_examples.sqlite: ALTER TABLE books ADD COLUMN in_stock BOOLEAN DEFAULT 1;
compat_examples.oracle: ALTER TABLE books ADD (in_stock NUMBER(1) DEFAULT 1)

sections.narrative: Use DEFAULTs and idempotent patterns. For complex changes, use staging tables and backfills.
sections.nerd_notes: See file altertable.json for more robust patterns (type change, rename, constraints).

sections.title: 4. Mid-lesson cleanup (authors/books)

examples.name: drop_cleanup
examples.sql: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS books; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS authors;
examples.description: Question: What's the safest way to drop demo objects so I can re-run examples?
examples.nerd_notes: DROP IF EXISTS avoids errors on repeated runs. Consider backups before dropping in real systems.

compat_examples.postgres: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS books; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS authors;
compat_examples.mysql: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS books; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS authors;
compat_examples.sqlite: DROP TABLE IF EXISTS books; DROP TABLE IF EXISTS authors;
compat_examples.oracle: BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE 'DROP TABLE books'; EXCEPTION WHEN OTHERS THEN NULL; END; BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE 'DROP TABLE authors'; EXCEPTION WHEN OTHERS THEN NULL; END;

sections.narrative: Tear down objects created in this lesson so the examples are repeatable and safe to re-run.
sections.nerd_notes: Prefer targeted cleanup to avoid interfering with other lessons.

sections.title: 5. Appendix: publishers demo
sections.narrative: A compact, runnable guide showing common DDL operations in DuckDB. Each example is idempotent (uses DROP IF EXISTS or IF NOT EXISTS).
sections.nerd_notes: These examples create small demo objects and are safe to run multiple times in the validation harness.

examples.name: publishers_table_example
examples.description: Create a small `publishers` table and insert demo rows (idempotent).
examples.nerd_notes: Demonstrates DROP IF EXISTS + CREATE + INSERT pattern so the example can be re-run safely.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE publishers (publisher_id INT PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT, country TEXT);
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TABLE publishers (publisher_id INT PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR(255), country VARCHAR(100));
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE publishers (publisher_id NUMBER PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR2(255), country VARCHAR2(100));

sections.title: 6. Basic CREATE TABLE
sections.narrative: Show a minimal CREATE TABLE pattern that is safe to run repeatedly.
sections.nerd_notes: Keep CREATE examples idempotent using DROP IF EXISTS or CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS.

examples.name: basic_create_table
examples.description: Create a basic `genres` table and insert sample rows.
examples.nerd_notes: Use NOT NULL constraints where appropriate; choose types conservatively for small demos.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE genres (genre_id INT PRIMARY KEY, name TEXT NOT NULL);
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TABLE genres (genre_id INT PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL);
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE genres (genre_id NUMBER PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR2(255) NOT NULL);

sections.title: 7. CREATE TABLE AS SELECT
sections.narrative: Create a derived table using `CREATE TABLE ... AS SELECT` from an inline VALUES table.
sections.nerd_notes: This pattern is useful to snapshot results of a query into a real table.

examples.name: create_table_as_select
examples.description: Create `top_publishers` from inline data using CTAS.
examples.nerd_notes: CTAS copies query results into a persistent table; we used VALUES to keep the example self-contained.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE top_publishers AS SELECT 1 AS publisher_id, 'HarborPress' AS name, 1000 AS sales UNION ALL SELECT 2, 'MapleBooks', 750;
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TABLE top_publishers AS SELECT 1 AS publisher_id, 'HarborPress' AS name, 1000 AS sales UNION ALL SELECT 2, 'MapleBooks', 750;
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE top_publishers AS SELECT 1 AS publisher_id, 'HarborPress' AS name, 1000 AS sales FROM dual UNION ALL SELECT 2, 'MapleBooks', 750 FROM dual;

sections.title: 8. CTAS with explicit types (CAST)
sections.narrative: Ensure desired column types when creating from a SELECT by casting in the projection.
sections.nerd_notes: CTAS infers types from the SELECT; add CASTs to control precision/scale and NULLability.

examples.name: ctas_with_types
examples.description: Question: How do I control column types in CTAS?
examples.nerd_notes: Explicit casts in the SELECT ensure consistent types regardless of source expression defaults.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE sales_ctas AS SELECT 1::int AS id, 'Widget'::text AS item, 9.99::numeric(10,2) AS price;
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TABLE sales_ctas AS SELECT CAST(1 AS SIGNED) id, CAST('Widget' AS CHAR(255)) item, CAST(9.99 AS DECIMAL(10,2)) price;
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE sales_ctas AS SELECT CAST(1 AS NUMBER) id, CAST('Widget' AS VARCHAR2(255)) item, CAST(9.99 AS NUMBER(10,2)) price FROM dual;

sections.title: 9. CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS
sections.narrative: Create a table only if it doesn’t already exist.
sections.nerd_notes: In teaching code we usually prefer DROP IF EXISTS + CREATE for determinism; IF NOT EXISTS is useful in idempotent bootstraps.

examples.name: create_if_not_exists
examples.description: Question: How can I avoid errors when a table may already exist?

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS maybe_table (id int, note text);
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS maybe_table (id INT, note VARCHAR(255));
compat_examples.oracle:
-- Use PL/SQL to create if not exists
-- BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE 'CREATE TABLE maybe_table (id NUMBER, note VARCHAR2(255))'; EXCEPTION WHEN OTHERS THEN IF SQLCODE = -955 THEN NULL ELSE RAISE; END IF; END;

sections.title: 10. DROP TABLE and Safe Deletion
sections.narrative: Demonstrate removing objects safely using IF EXISTS.
sections.nerd_notes: Prefer DROP IF EXISTS to make examples re-runnable.

examples.name: drop_table_safe
examples.description: Drop demo tables created earlier to keep the environment clean.
examples.nerd_notes: Cleanup steps help the validator avoid cross-example interference.

compat_examples.oracle: BEGIN EXECUTE IMMEDIATE 'DROP TABLE top_publishers'; EXCEPTION WHEN OTHERS THEN NULL; END;

sections.title: 11. TRUNCATE TABLE (DELETE Equivalent)
sections.narrative: DuckDB supports DELETE; use DELETE FROM to remove rows in examples.
sections.nerd_notes: TRUNCATE may not be available in all backends; DELETE is portable in DuckDB for demos.

examples.name: delete_equivalent
examples.description: Show using DELETE to clear a table and verify the rowcount.
examples.nerd_notes: DELETE removes rows; for larger datasets consider partitioning or file-level operations.

sections.title: 12. Copy structure only (LIKE pattern)
sections.narrative: Create an empty table with the same structure as another table.
sections.nerd_notes: DuckDB doesn't have CREATE TABLE LIKE; use CTAS with WHERE 1=0 to copy the shape.

examples.name: create_like_pattern
examples.description: Question: How can I create a new table with the same columns but no rows?
examples.nerd_notes: The WHERE 1=0 trick returns zero rows but preserves columns and defaults when supported by CTAS.

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TABLE src_demo_copy (LIKE src_demo INCLUDING ALL);
compat_examples.sqlite: CREATE TABLE src_demo_copy AS SELECT * FROM src_demo WHERE 0;
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE TABLE src_demo_copy AS SELECT * FROM src_demo WHERE 1=0

sections.title: 13. Temporary tables
sections.narrative: Use temporary tables for session-scoped scratch work.
sections.nerd_notes: Temporary tables live for the connection/session and don't require manual cleanup.

examples.name: temp_tables_demo
examples.description: Question: How do I create and use a temporary table?
examples.sql:
CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE temp_nums AS SELECT * FROM range(5) AS t(i);
SELECT COUNT(*) AS n FROM temp_nums;

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE TEMP TABLE temp_nums AS SELECT generate_series(0,4) AS i;
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE temp_nums (i INT); INSERT INTO temp_nums VALUES (0),(1),(2),(3),(4);
compat_examples.oracle: CREATE GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE temp_nums (i NUMBER) ON COMMIT PRESERVE ROWS; INSERT INTO temp_nums SELECT LEVEL-1 FROM dual CONNECT BY LEVEL <= 5;

sections.title: 14. Schemas and namespacing (DDL)
sections.narrative: Create a schema and a table within it, then clean up.
sections.nerd_notes: DuckDB supports schemas; qualify with schema.table. Default schema is main.

examples.name: schema_namespace
examples.description: Question: How do I create a schema and table within it?

compat_examples.postgres: CREATE SCHEMA s_demo; CREATE TABLE s_demo.metrics (k TEXT, v INT);
compat_examples.mysql: CREATE DATABASE s_demo; CREATE TABLE s_demo.metrics (k VARCHAR(255), v INT);
compat_examples.oracle: -- In Oracle, schema == user; qualify as user.table (requires user s_demo).

sections.title: 15. Final cleanup (lesson-wide)
sections.narrative: Drop any demo objects that may linger from previous sections to keep the environment clean.

examples.name: final_cleanup
examples.description: Ensure all objects created in this lesson are removed.
examples.nerd_notes: Keeping a final cleanup makes re-validation deterministic.

exercises.answer_sql: SELECT author_id, COUNT(*) AS cnt FROM authors GROUP BY author_id ORDER BY cnt DESC;

exercises.prompt: Select the top 10 rows where `author_id` is positive (if numeric) or not null otherwise.
exercises.answer_sql: SELECT * FROM authors WHERE author_id IS NOT NULL AND author_id > 0 LIMIT 10;
